title: Q20 - Language Facility
prompt:
(20) What is the most effective way to combine these sentences?

I sit at the table with my bowl of cereal. I’m barely able to keep still. I wait for my dad to appear.
description: Read through the draft of an anecdote about April Fool’s Day. Then go on to the suggestions for revision that follow.
feedback: The best combination of these sentences is “Barely able to keep still, I sit at the table with my bowl of cereal as I wait for my dad to appear.” The phrase “barely able to keep still” modifies “I,” so it makes sense to have to near the subject. It shouldn’t appear to modify “bowl of cereal” or “table.” The choice that includes “I wait for my dad to appear with my bowl of cereal” is incorrect, since it sounds like the dad will be carrying a bowl of cereal. That’s not the same meaning. The choice “I sit at the table with my bowl of cereal, and I’m barely able to keep still, and I wait for my dad to appear” is a run-on sentence with three main clauses.
